name: Laura Behnke
bio:
👋🏻 Tossing out societal norms
👶🏼 IVF mom after 40
💥 Stage III rectal cancer survivor
🎧 host @thelifeactuallypodcast
📍 SF Bay Area
#ownyourtimeline

social_posts.post_text:
The penultimate chemo infusion has begun. Just one more to go after this and yet at times I find myself struggling mentally. The side effects are brutal but I keep reminding myself that everything is temporary. I will not feel this way forever. It will end. I can do this. I will do this.

After five weeks of radiation and now nine weeks of chemo infusions there are just six more weeks to go. After that it’s time to focus on a pretty major surgery in February.

I’m so grateful for the support I’ve received from so many people, many I’ve never even met. A cancer diagnosis is incredibly isolating. At the end of the day it’s just you and the treatments. But knowing how much people care is something I hold very tightly to my heart.

I could not get through this without my family. It’s Marc’s unwavering love and those big blue eyes of Mari’s that constantly remind me why I fight.

I am okay. I will be okay. Thank you for the love ❤️ #cancerfighter #cancersupport #cancerpatient

Today is Mari’s first birthday! And my emotions are all over the place.

I’ve been crying a lot since last night as everything that has happened in these past 12 months really started to hit me. It’s been the hardest, most emotional year of my life. From a birth that was long, hard and completely NOT how I planned it, to the dark and difficult days postpartum to the darker and even more difficult days post chemo, it has been A LOT. 

I’m not really at the place yet where I can say I’m just so grateful to be here fighting. Because I’m still angry that there has been so much fighting to be done. And probably will be angry for a long time. My only baby is one today and for nearly half of her short life I’ve been sick.

But so many things are beyond my control. All I can do is keep fighting and keep loving. This little girl has shown me what I am capable of. And being here with her and her dad is all that really matters to me.

So, I’ll let the tears flow today. I’ll also laugh and smile and hold my family close. If there’s one thing this past year has taught me it’s to take nothing for granted. And to always remember that everything is temporary. The tough stuff doesn’t last forever. And while it may be replaced with even tougher stuff, that, too, will ease with time.

Happy first birthday, Mari Grace. And congrats to Marc and me for keeping a small human alive for an entire year ❤️

This little nugget recently turned 14 months old and that’s when it became official: for over half of Mari’s life I have been a cancer patient. But all of that is about to change.

My scans came back clean and showed a complete response to my treatment. There is no trace of cancer in my body. I still had pretty major surgery last month to remove all of the areas that were originally affected, just to be safe. And the biopsy on those showed no residual cancer.

I have one more surgery at the end of this month to reverse the temporary ileostomy I currently have. The recovery has been hard and I still have a long road ahead.

But this we celebrate. There is still physical pain and a lot of emotional trauma to acknowledge, but the treatment chapter of this story is almost over. 💙💙
.
.
.
.
#cancerpatient #cancersucks #colorectalcancer #colorectalcancerawareness #fuckcancer #lifewithcancer #lifeaftercancer #cancersurvivor

BEFORE and AFTER my third and final (!!) surgery. The ostomy bag and port are gone 🎉 I got home from the hospital yesterday and while I’m in a lot of pain I know the only thing ahead is recovery. No more surgery or treatment setbacks. This is it. Just hope and healing ❤️ #ownyourtimeline #cancersucks #colorectalcancer

The result of trying to get a cute Mother’s Day photo with a 16-month-old who just isn’t having it 😆🤷🏼‍♀️ But I definitely appreciate this day!

For a terribly long weekend last July in between my colonoscopy on a Friday afternoon (when my surgeon said “it looks like cancer”) and the official diagnosis on Monday I wasn’t sure I’d have any more Mother’s Days.

Before having any information on my staging or treatment plan I was convinced I was going to die. Just hearing the word “cancer” brought up everything we had just gone through with my father-in-law and my own dad. And a positive result just didn’t seem possible.

But it was and it is.

And here we are. Every day isn’t filled with rainbows and butterflies but that isn’t what I went through treatment for. It was to have more perfectly imperfect days with the people I love.

Even if we don’t always have cute pictures to prove it. #ownyourtimeline #cancersurvivor

I know it was just a vacation but I don’t think I can overstate what our anniversary trip to Mexico meant to me. 

My first surgery—the big one, low anterior resection—was 15 weeks ago. And from the moment I woke up in recovery, in agonizing pain and with a temporary ileostomy bag, I have been thinking of this trip. 

Not in an, “it will be so nice to have a vacation!” kind of way. Though, sure, I was excited for that aspect, too.

For me, the idea of going to Mexico was my constant reminder that everything I was going through was temporary. I wasn’t going to feel this terrible forever. I would find a way back to “normal” once again. Because if I could travel to Mexico then I had to be getting more of myself back. 

Mexico would be my proof that I was going to be okay.

So, when we finally arrived I was an emotional rollercoaster. Honestly, both Marc and I were. The last year has been A LOT. We’re both still trying to process it all.

This trip wasn’t quite “normal” for me. I still have months of recovery ahead as my body settles into whatever “normal” will now mean for me.

But I’ve moved from cancer patient into life as a survivor, with an emphasis on “life”.

My first followup with my oncologist is tomorrow. Our appointments every three months, along with my continuous scans, are a reminder you’re never quite done with cancer.

But I’m ready to finally start focusing on everything else. I’m ready to be okay again. #ownyourtimeline #rectalcancer #cancersurvivor

I have seven scars you can see and countless ones you can’t. This is what survivorship looks like for me.

Today is #NationalCancerSurvivorsDay and somehow that now includes me. In many ways I still can’t believe any of this actually happened.

But these seven scars remind me every day.

There’s one near my right shoulder that is from the port used to administer life-saving chemo. There are four small ones from my first surgery, the low anterior resection that was done robotically and lasted over seven hours. That’s also when my surgeon opened part of my c-section scar in order to remove the affected part of my rectum and colon, along with 17 lymph nodes.

And there’s the larger scar to the right of my belly button, the result of my second surgery, the ileostomy reversal. It’s still tender nine weeks later.

They are all beginning to fade a bit, or maybe I’m just getting used to them. Either way, they’re now a part of me.

The first thing I learned about cancer is that when a surgeon says “it looks like cancer”, it almost certainly is. They can’t say for certain without the pathology reports. But that isn’t a word they use lightly.

And what I’m continuing to learn now, nearly one year later, is that you’re never done with cancer. I’m still alive, but I’ll be dealing with physical, mental and emotional repercussions for the rest of my life.

But I have a life to live, and that is what matters. Even though I’m still processing my feelings about gratitude and how to balance that with the anger that is still very strong.

It’s a work in progress. I’m a work in progress. And these scars remind me every day that that is okay. #NCSD2023 #rectalcancer #cancersurvivor #ownyourtimeline

There’s a tight rope balance between anger and gratitude and I feel I’ve been walking it a lot lately.

I’m so grateful to be here, to be living.

And I’m still angry that any of that was ever in doubt.

I’m angry my body doesn’t look, feel or act the way it used to.

And I’m grateful I even have a body to worry about.

I’m angry so much of my life has been on hold so I could willingly put my body through absolute hell just to try to get back to where I was before my diagnosis.

And I’m grateful pieces of that life are starting to return and that I have the option to speed up or slow down as needed.

I’m angry at what my diagnosis has done to the people I love. The fear, anxiety, stress and sadness it has heaped onto their lives.

And I’m so incredibly grateful for those people who have held my hand and stood with me in the face of such trauma.

The truth is you don’t have to feel just one. It’s okay to be angry and grateful. Happy and sad. Scared and hopeful.

I’m trying to remind myself of this every day. To give myself the grace needed to process the past year. And the permission to feel it all so that I can keep moving forward.

I’m angry and I’m grateful. 

Because I’m human. #ownyourtimeline #cancersurvivor #rectalcancer #cancerjourney

“We found a mass. It looks like cancer.” One year ago today I heard those words. It’s cliche but true—my life would never be the same again.

I came out of anesthesia from my colonoscopy to hear my surgeon on the other side of the curtain  tell the nurse that she would speak to me when I woke up and to “make sure her husband is with her”. That’s when I knew.

Meanwhile, Marc was in the waiting room and started to hear the nurses and receptionist begin talking about ordering tests and scans for a patient STAT. And he knew it was me.

Since then we got the official diagnosis: stage 3 rectal cancer. I had five weeks of daily radiation, followed by five cycles of chemo over 15 weeks, major low anterior resection surgery, an ileostomy bag, followed by an ileostomy reversal.

It has been a truly terrible year. But I made it through with clean scans and zero sign of cancer.

My journey is far from over. There are months of recovery still ahead, both physical and emotional.

On some level cancer is forever. But this past year has shown me that everything is temporary.

And tonight we’ll raise a glass. Not to celebrate a cancer anniversary but to celebrate resilience and survival. #cancersurvivor #rectalcancer #colorectalcancersurvivor #cancerjourney #ownyourtimeline

This is not Tahoe 🤷🏼‍♀️

This past weekend was supposed to be spent in Tahoe with good friends. We packed everything up, loaded it all in to the car along with the dog and the baby and set off on Thursday afternoon.

Friday afternoon we were on our way home.

Ugh!

It was supposed to be our first weekend trip as a family. It was supposed to be a chance to shake up Mari’s routine and expose her to new places and people. And it was supposed to be a chance to prove to myself that I am healing and ready to do “normal” things again.

Yeah, about that…

For a variety of reasons it became pretty clear pretty quickly that my body just isn’t ready for this. Oxford kept us up all night barking at every noise he heard. In the past I could deal with that. But right now my GI tract can not. And it sent my body into a tailspin. One I’m still trying to recover from four days later.

As I lay awake that night I tried to talk myself into doing what we came to do—staying through the weekend and keeping the plans we made with our friends. Because the last thing I wanted to do was inconvenience anyone else.

But the reality is that right now I have to pretty much only think about what I need—what my body needs as it heals and recovers. Because I can’t do anything for anyone else unless I’m okay.

And in Tahoe I was not okay.

So we decided to call it.

I cried. I apologized. I felt incredibly guilty and disappointed.

But I did what was best for me.

Just over 24 hours after we left our house we returned. The rest of the weekend was spent relaxing in the backyard and in the pool. Marc and I were able to get out for a lunch date while my mom watched Mari. And I got the sleep I needed to help my body start figuring things out again.

It isn’t what I wanted. But it’s what I needed. And I’m proud of myself for choosing the one that matters most. #ownyourtimeline #cancerrecovery #cancersurvivor #rectalcancer #cancerjourney
